questions.text: A previously healthy 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 3-week history of fever, fatigue, and malaise. His mother says she noticed a significant decrease in his appetite and overall activity level. He is homeschooled and has had no sick contacts. There are no pets at home, but he often visits a feline animal shelter where his mother volunteers. Temperature is 38.4°C (101.2°F). Physical examination shows a 1-cm papular lesion on the back of the right hand. He also has tender, bulky lymphadenopathy of the axillae and groin. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic treatment with doxycycline is recommended for immunocompromised individuals with localized CSD and for most patients with extranodal CSD. This patient has localized CSD and is not immunocompromised, so doxycycline is not the most appropriate antibiotic therapy. Additionally, if antibiotic treatment is necessary for a young child with extranodal CSD and/or immunocompromised status, erythromycin should be considered instead of doxycycline to avoid its possible side effects (e.g., tooth enamel hypoplasia, permanent tooth discoloration).

B) INCORRECT:

Pyrimethamine is an antiprotozoal drug used in the treatment of toxoplasmosis, which is extremely rare in immunocompetent hosts. If symptoms occur, they are usually limited to painless, cervical lymphadenopathy, as opposed to the findings in this patient (papule on the hand, diffuse lymphadenopathy).

C) INCORRECT:

Itraconazole can be used for treating sporotrichosis caused by the fungus Sporothrix schenckii, which is usually transmitted through small skin lesions when handling soil or moss. The most common presentation is a papule that may ulcerate, usually without any systemic symptoms. In rare cases, sporotrichosis may spread to other organs such as the lungs and cause systemic symptoms, but this almost exclusively occurs in immunocompromised patients.

D) CORRECT:

Antibiotic treatment is usually not required in immunocompetent patients with localized CSD because the infection is self-limited. However, azithromycin can be used to reduce lymphadenopathy and illness duration. Treatment with erythromycin or doxycycline is recommended for immunocompromised individuals with localized CSD and patients with extranodal CSD.
Image Description:

A solitary reddish-purple papule on an erythematous base is visible on the patient's right thenar eminence.

This appearance is typical of cat scratch disease, i.e., infection with Bartonella henselae.

E) INCORRECT:

Streptomycin is an aminoglycoside effective against Yersinia pestis, which is spread through flea bites and causes the plague. The most common subtype is bubonic plague, which also manifests with fever and weakness, followed by tender lymphadenopathy. Lymphadenopathy indicates that the infection has spread from the initial entry point on the hand throughout the body. In the case of plague, the presence of lymphadenopathy would indicate a severe and systemic course, often with gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., diarrhea, vomiting), followed by shock and multiple organ failure.
questions.hint: The cutaneous lesion on the patient's hand combined with bulky lymphadenopathy and a history of exposure to cats raises suspicion for localized cat scratch disease (CSD).

questions.text: A previously healthy 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of generalized malaise and a palpable swelling in the left axilla. The parents report that 2 weeks ago, his daycare group visited an animal shelter, after which he developed a rash on the left hand. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F). Physical examination shows three linear crusts on an erythematous background on the dorsum of the left hand. There is tender left-sided axillary and cervical lymphadenopathy. Microscopic examination of an axillary lymph node shows necrotizing granulomas. The most likely causal organism of this patient's clinical findings is also involved in the pathogenesis of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Kaposi sarcoma is caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8), not Bartonella henselae. Kaposi sarcoma typically manifests with purple or dark brown/black macules, plaques, and nodules on the skin. The gastrointestinal tract, mucous membranes of the mouth, and regional lymph nodes can also be affected.
Image Description:

A mixture of dark red macules, papules, and plaques are distributed asymmetrically on the skin.

These lesions are characteristic of Kaposi sarcoma (caused by human herpesvirus 8).

B) CORRECT:

Bacillary angiomatosis is caused by Bartonella henselae (as well as Bartonella quintana) and typically manifests with proliferative, vascular lesions on the skin. The characteristic lesions are small, red-purple papules that can expand into larger, pedunculated lesions that have a tendency to bleed. Unlike cat scratch disease, which can affect immunocompetent individuals (such as this previously healthy boy), bacillary angiomatosis typically affects individuals who are immunosuppressed.

Bacillary angiomatosis lesions can mimic Kaposi sarcoma but have a characteristic neutrophilic infiltrate on histopathologic examination.
Image Description:

A solitary reddish-purple papule on an erythematous base is visible on the patient's right thenar eminence.

This appearance is typical of cat scratch disease, i.e., infection with Bartonella henselae.

C) INCORRECT:

Burkitt lymphoma is caused by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), not Bartonella henselae. Burkitt lymphoma typically manifests with a rapidly growing tumor mass, characteristically in the jaw. EBV also causes infectious mononucleosis and is associated with Hodgkin lymphoma, primary CNS lymphoma, oral hairy leukoplakia, and pharyngeal carcinoma.
Image Description:

Seven-year-old boy from Nigeria

A massive swelling with central ulceration and peripheral scaling is visible above the right mandible.

The age and origin of the boy as well as the localization of the lymphoma most likely indicate the endemic form of Burkitt lymphoma (mainly found in Africa), which is associated with the Epstein Barr virus (EBV).

D) INCORRECT:

Condylomata lata are seen in secondary syphilis, a sexually transmitted disease caused by Treponema pallidum, not Bartonella henselae. They typically manifests with raised, gray-white lesions that develop in warm, moist areas such as the mouth and perineum. Additional symptoms of secondary syphilis include generalized lymphadenopathy, constitutional symptoms, a disseminated, maculopapular rash that affects the palms and soles, and patchy alopecia.
Image Description:

Broad-based papular erosions are visible around this patient's anus.

Clustering around the anus and the typical appearance are suggestive of condylomata lata, a sign of secondary syphilis.

E) INCORRECT:

Brucellosis is caused by Brucella bacteria, not Bartonella henselae. Similar to cat scratch disease, brucellosis is transmitted by animals, usually after contact with fluids from infected animals or contaminated food products such as unpasteurized milk and cheese. It typically manifests with nonspecific, flu-like symptoms and can cause undulant fever.

F) INCORRECT:

Bubonic plague is caused by Yersinia pestis, not Bartonella henselae. Bubonic plague typically manifests with the sudden onset of fever, headache, myalgias, and painful, swollen lymph nodes (buboes) in the groin and/or axillae.
Image Description:

Right axilla of a male patient diagnosed with plague

The axilla appears swollen secondary to underlying lymph node enlargement due to infection with Yersinia pestis.

This disease is rare but if diagnosed requires immediate antibiotic treatment.
questions.hint: This patient presents with fever and tender, unilateral lymphadenopathy 2 weeks after exposure to animals. The linear crusts on his hand are likely from an animal scratch that introduced the organism responsible for his symptoms. These features indicate a diagnosis of cat scratch disease, which is caused by Bartonella henselae. The presence of necrotizing granulomas on histopathologic examination confirms the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the physician because of fever and painful swelling in his right axilla for 1 week. He feels tired and reports a loss of appetite. He works in a garden center during weekdays and at a pet shop that sells various pet mammals and fish during the weekends. He smokes one pack of cigarettes daily and occasionally marijuana. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 95/min, and blood pressure is 131/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows tender, erythematous, and fluctuant right axillary lymph node swelling with oozing purulent discharge. There is an erythematous papule on the right index finger. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely infectious agent?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Toxoplasma gondii is a parasite that is most commonly transmitted via the ingestion of cysts (e.g., from cat feces) and causes toxoplasmosis. Most immunocompetent individuals with toxoplasmosis are asymptomatic or have fever and lymphadenopathy, both of which are seen here. However, the adenopathy is typically nontender, bilateral, and affects the cervical lymph nodes, whereas this patient has unilateral, tender, suppurative, axillary lymphadenopathy. In addition, erythematous skin lesions are not characteristic of toxoplasmosis.

B) CORRECT:

Bartonella henselae is a gram‑negative bacterium that is commonly found in cats and transmitted to humans via a scratch or a bite. It can lead to a benign, self-limiting disease (i.e., cat scratch disease) or disseminated disease in immunocompromised patients (i.e., bacillary angiomatosis). This patient's exposure to animals at the pet shop puts him at risk for developing cat scratch disease, which initially manifests with fever, loss of appetite, and an erythematous, nontender cutaneous papule at the site of inoculation, all of which are seen here. Lymphadenopathy develops shortly after the initial symptoms, and is usually tender, unilateral, and localized near the site of the inoculation (most commonly in the axillary nodes).
Image Description:

A solitary reddish-purple papule on an erythematous base is visible on the patient's right thenar eminence.

This appearance is typical of cat scratch disease, i.e., infection with Bartonella henselae.

C) INCORRECT:

Vibrio vulnificus is a gram-negative bacillus that can be transmitted via contaminated seawater that has come into contact with open wounds. This patient's exposure to fish at the pet shop puts him at risk for developing a V. vulnificus infection, which can cause cellulitis and also manifest with an erythematous skin lesion, fever, and lymphadenopathy. However, suppuration of the lymph nodes is not characteristic of V. vulnificus cellulitis and the symptoms typically develop more acutely.

D) INCORRECT:

Pasteurella multocida is a gram‑negative coccobacillus that can cause cellulitis secondary to dog or cat bites. Although cellulitis might explain this patient's erythematous skin lesion, lymphadenopathy, and fever, it does not lead to suppuration of the lymph nodes and it typically manifests more acutely, making a different diagnosis more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Sporothrix schenckii is a dimorphic fungus that is found on vegetation and garden soil and leads to sporotrichosis, which initially manifests as an erythematous papule at the site of inoculation. However, most patients with sporotrichosis develop subcutaneous nodules and ulcers along the draining lymphatic vessels (nodular ascending lymphangitis) rather than isolated suppurative lymphadenopathy. In addition, sporotrichosis does not usually manifest with systemic symptoms such as fever and loss of appetite.
Image Description:

Photograph of the left arm of a patient

There are several large, nodular lesions on the left arm. The largest and most distal lesion is ulcerated. The chain-like pattern of these lesions follows a lymphocutaneous distribution.

This is the typical appearance of lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis.
questions.hint: Histopathological examination of the lesion will show necrotizing granulomas.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman reports a 2-week history of swelling behind her left ear. She does not have any systemic symptoms and has not noticed swelling elsewhere on her body. She recently lost about 2.3 kg and currently smokes. She states that she has been sexually active with one male partner in the past year and has used condoms consistently with him. She has a newly acquired kitten, who recently scratched her, and she keeps an aquarium. She has no known exposure to tuberculosis.
Examination reveals a tender, retroauricular fluctuant lymph node measuring 2 cm by 2 cm behind her left earlobe (figure). No other lymph nodes are enlarged.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in managing this patient's lymphadenopathy?

choices.text: Aspirate the lymph node; send material for acid-fast bacilli culture
Perform serologic testing for Bartonella henselae
Perform excisional biopsy of the lymph node; send tissue for pathological examination
Perform incision and drainage of the lymph node in the office; send material for wound culture

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Interferon-gamma release assays are done to diagnose latent tuberculosis infection; in this case, that diagnosis is less likely than cat-scratch disease because the patient had no known exposure to tuberculosis.

B) INCORRECT:

In cat-scratch disease, the lymphadenopathy will resolve on its own. If the lymph node persists or if the presentation is atypical, further diagnostic testing, such as aspiration, should be pursued. In this case, tuberculosis is less likely than cat-scratch disease because the patient had no known exposure to tuberculosis.

C) CORRECT:

Lymphadenitis in a patient with a recent scratch from a kitten suggests cat-scratch disease from Bartonella henselae. This infection usually begins with a primary cutaneous papule or pustule approximately 3 to 10 days after animal contact. Most commonly, regional lymphadenopathy develops ipsilateral to the inoculation site (mainly head, neck, or upper extremity). There may be overlying erythema and, in 10% to 15% of cases, the lymph nodes may suppurate. Nearly half of patients with cat-scratch disease have single lymph node involvement, 20% have multiple node involvement at one site, and the remaining one-third have node involvement at multiple sites. The diagnosis is confirmed with serologic testing.

In cat-scratch disease, the lymphadenopathy will resolve on its own. If the lymph node persists or if the presentation is atypical, further diagnostic testing, such as aspiration or excisional biopsy, should be pursued.

Key learning point: Lymphadenitis in a patient with a recent scratch from a kitten suggests a diagnosis of cat-scratch disease due to Bartonella henselae.


D) INCORRECT:

In cat-scratch disease, the lymphadenopathy will resolve on its own. If the lymph node persists or if the presentation is atypical, further diagnostic testing, such as aspiration, should be pursued.

E) INCORRECT:

Incision and drainage is generally used to treat skin and soft-tissue abscesses; it is not required if the lymphadenitis is due to Bartonella.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old girl presents with a 2-week history of swelling behind her left ear. She does not have any systemic symptoms and has not noticed swelling elsewhere on her body. Her family has a newly acquired kitten which recently scratched her, and she has an aquarium in her bedroom. She has no recent travel or known exposure to tuberculosis.
Examination reveals a red, tender, retroauricular fluctuant lymph node measuring 2 cm by 2 cm behind her left earlobe (figure). No other lymph nodes are enlarged.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in managing this patient's lymphadenopathy?

choices.text: Perform excisional biopsy of the lymph node; send tissue for pathological examination
Initiate empiric antibiotic therapy with cephalexin
Perform incision and drainage of the lymph node in the office; send material for wound culture
Perform serologic testing for Bartonella henselae
Aspirate the lymph node; send material for acid-fast bacilli culture

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In cat-scratch disease, the lymphadenopathy will resolve on its own. If the lymph node persists or if the presentation is atypical, further diagnostic testing, such as aspiration or excisional biopsy, should be pursued.

B) INCORRECT:

Although some antibiotics (particularly macrolides) have shown efficacy against Bartonella, a diagnostic workup should be conducted before antibiotics are initiated. Cephalexin, a beta-lactam antibiotic, has not been shown to be efficacious in this setting.

C) INCORRECT:

Incision and drainage is generally used to treat skin and soft-tissue abscesses; it is not required if the lymphadenitis is due to Bartonella.

D) CORRECT:

Lymphadenitis in a patient with a recent scratch from a kitten suggests cat-scratch disease from Bartonella henselae. This infection usually begins with a primary cutaneous papule or pustule approximately 3 to 10 days after animal contact. Most commonly, regional lymphadenopathy develops ipsilateral to the inoculation site (mainly head, neck, or upper extremity). There may be overlying erythema and, in 10% to 15% of cases, the lymph nodes may suppurate. Nearly half of patients with cat-scratch disease have single lymph node involvement, 20% have multiple node involvement at one site, and the remaining one-third have node involvement at multiple sites. The diagnosis is confirmed with serologic testing.

Key learning point: Lymphadenitis in a patient with a recent scratch from a kitten suggests a diagnosis of cat-scratch disease due to Bartonella henselae.

E) INCORRECT:

In cat-scratch disease, the lymphadenopathy will resolve on its own. If the lymph node persists or if the presentation is atypical, further diagnostic testing, such as aspiration or excisional biopsy, should be pursued.

A) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic treatment with doxycycline is recommended for individuals with immunocompromise and localized CSD, and for most patients with extranodal CSD. Pyrimethamine is an antiprotozoal drug used in the treatment of toxoplasmosis, which is extremely rare in immunocompetent hosts. If symptoms occur, they are usually limited to painless, cervical lymphadenopathy, as opposed to the findings in this patient (papule on the hand, diffuse lymphadenopathy).

Antibiotic treatment is usually not required in immunocompetent patients with localized CSD because the infection is self-limited. However, azithromycin can be used to reduce lymphadenopathy and illness duration. Treatment with erythromycin or doxycycline is recommended for individuals with immunocompromise and localized CSD and patients with extranodal CSD.

A solitary reddish-purple papule on an erythematous base is visible on the patient's right thenar eminence.

This appearance is typical of cat scratch disease, i.e., infection with Bartonella henselae.

Streptomycin is an aminoglycoside effective against Yersinia pestis, which is spread through flea bites and causes the plague. Lymphadenopathy indicates that the infection has spread from the initial entry point on the hand throughout the body. In rare cases, sporotrichosis may spread to other organs such as the lungs and cause systemic symptoms, but this almost exclusively occurs in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the office because of fever and painful swelling in his right axilla for 1 week. He feels tired and reports a loss of appetite. He works in a garden center during weekdays and at a pet shop that sells various pet mammals and fish during the weekends. He smokes one pack of cigarettes daily and occasionally marijuana. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 95/min, and blood pressure is 131/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows tender, erythematous, and fluctuant right axillary lymph node swelling with oozing purulent discharge. There is an erythematous papule on the right index finger. Toxoplasma gondii is a parasite that is most commonly transmitted via the ingestion of cysts (e.g., from cat feces) and causes toxoplasmosis. Most immunocompetent individuals with toxoplasmosis are asymptomatic or have fever and lymphadenopathy, both of which are seen here. However, the adenopathy is typically nontender, bilateral, and affects the cervical lymph nodes, whereas this patient has unilateral, tender, suppurative, axillary lymphadenopathy. In addition, erythematous skin lesions are not characteristic of toxoplasmosis.

Bartonella henselae is a gram‑negative bacterium that is commonly found in cats and transmitted to humans via a scratch or a bite. It can lead to a benign, self-limiting disease (i.e., cat-scratch disease) or disseminated disease in immunocompromised patients (i.e., bacillary angiomatosis). This patient's exposure to animals at the pet shop puts him at risk for developing cat-scratch disease, which initially manifests with fever, loss of appetite, and an erythematous, nontender cutaneous papule at the site of inoculation, all of which are seen here. Lymphadenopathy develops shortly after the initial symptoms, and is usually tender, unilateral, and localized near the site of the inoculation (most commonly in the axillary nodes).
Image Description:

A solitary reddish-purple papule on an erythematous base is visible on the patient's right thenar eminence.

This appearance is typical of cat scratch disease, i.e., infection with Bartonella henselae.

Vibrio vulnificus is a gram-negative bacillus that can be transmitted via contaminated seawater that has come into contact with open wounds. However, suppuration of the lymph nodes is not characteristic of V. vulnificus cellulitis and the symptoms typically develop more acutely.

In addition, sporotrichosis does not usually manifest with systemic symptoms such as fever and loss of appetite.
Image Description:

Photograph of the left arm of a patient

There are several large, nodular lesions on the left arm. The largest and most distal lesion is ulcerated. The chain-like pattern of these lesions follows a lymphocutaneous distribution.

This is the typical appearance of lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis.

questions.text: You are seeing a previously healthy 5-year-old boy who is brought to your clinic by his mother because of a 3-week history of fever, fatigue, and malaise. His mother reports a significant decrease in his appetite and activity level. He is homeschooled and has had no known sick contacts. There are no pets at home, but he frequently visits a feline animal shelter where his mother volunteers. His temperature is 38.4°C. On examination, there is a 1-cm papular lesion on the back of his right hand. He has tender, bulky lymphadenopathy in the axillae and groin. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Antibiotic treatment is usually not required in immunocompetent patients with localized CSD because the infection is self-limited and resolves within 6 months. However, azithromycin can be used to reduce lymphadenopathy and illness duration. Treatment with erythromycin or doxycycline is recommended for individuals with immunocompromise and localized CSD, and for patients with extranodal CSD.

Key learning point: Cat scratch disease is a self-limited disease in immunocompetent patients, but azithromycin can reduce lymphadenopathy and illness duration.
Image Description:

A solitary reddish-purple papule on an erythematous base is visible on the patient's right thenar eminence.

This appearance is typical of cat scratch disease, i.e., infection with Bartonella henselae.

B) INCORRECT:

Pyrimethamine is an antiprotozoal drug used in the treatment of toxoplasmosis, which is extremely rare in immunocompetent hosts. If symptoms occur, they are usually limited to painless, cervical lymphadenopathy, as opposed to the findings in this patient (papule on the hand, diffuse lymphadenopathy).

C) INCORRECT:

Streptomycin is an aminoglycoside effective against Yersinia pestis, which is spread through flea bites and causes the plague. The most common subtype is bubonic plague, which also manifests with fever and weakness, followed by tender lymphadenopathy. Lymphadenopathy indicates that the infection has spread from the initial entry point on the hand throughout the body. However, plague is exceedingly rare, and plague has a very rapid onset and a fulminant course; high fever, chills, prostration, and painful buboes typically develop within days of exposure, whereas this boy has had a low-grade fever for three weeks.

D) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic treatment with doxycycline is recommended for individuals with immunocompromise and localized CSD, and for most patients with extranodal CSD. This patient has localized CSD and does not have immunocompromise, so doxycycline is not the most appropriate antibiotic therapy. Additionally, if antibiotic treatment is necessary for a young child with extranodal CSD and/or immunocompromise, erythromycin should be considered instead of doxycycline to avoid its possible side effects (e.g., tooth enamel hypoplasia, permanent tooth discoloration).

E) INCORRECT:

Itraconazole can be used for treating sporotrichosis caused by the fungus Sporothrix schenckii, which is usually transmitted through small skin lesions when handling soil or moss. The most common presentation is a papule that may ulcerate, usually without any systemic symptoms. In rare cases, sporotrichosis may spread to other organs such as the lungs and cause systemic symptoms, but this almost exclusively occurs in immunocompromised patients.
questions.hint: The cutaneous lesion on the patient's hand combined with bulky lymphadenopathy and a history of exposure to cats raises suspicion for localized cat scratch disease (CSD).

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with a 3-week history of painful left axillary swelling. She has also been experiencing low-grade fever and malaise over this period. Her mother reports that the swelling began about two weeks after a small, red bump appeared on her left forearm, which has since resolved.  She has no significant medical history and takes no medications. Vital signs are normal. On examination, there are several, tender, nonfluctuant, markedly enlarged lymph nodes in the left axilla. The overlying skin is slightly erythematous. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. The patient has two healthy cats at home that she frequently plays with. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Provide supportive care and schedule follow-up in 2–4 weeks
Perform incision and drainage of the lymph nodes

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Clindamycin is not a recommended antibiotic for cat scratch disease. While antibiotics may be considered for localized disease, azithromycin is preferred in immunocompetent patients. However, many patients do not require antibiotic therapy because the infection is self-limited.

B) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound can help differentiate between benign and malignant lymph nodes but is not currently indicated in this patient because the clinical presentation strongly suggests infectious lymphadenopathy.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient presents with classic localized cat scratch disease based on the history of cat exposure, characteristic timeline (skin papule followed by regional lymphadenopathy), and clinical findings. In immunocompetent patients with localized disease, treatment is often not required because the infection is typically self-limited and resolves within 6 months. Supportive care with close follow-up is appropriate.

D) INCORRECT:

Blood cultures are not indicated in this patient with characteristic features of localized cat scratch disease and a history of exposure to cats. Confirmatory studies, including serology, blood cultures, and/or histopathology are considered for the evaluation of extranodal cat scratch disease or when there is diagnostic uncertainty.

E) INCORRECT:

Incision and drainage of involved lymph nodes is avoided in cat scratch disease due to the risk of fistula formation. Aspiration may be considered for symptom relief in patients with painful suppurative lymph nodes but is not indicated in this patient with nonfluctuant lymph nodes.
